revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1) ([[User:Balon Greyjoy|Balon Greyjoy]])
/* top */replaced: Senior Vice President → senior vice president, Vice President → vice president, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: February of 2018 → February 2018, etc.
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Stratfor | logo = Stratfor_logo_and_tagline-Your_World_In_Context-2017.jpg | type = [[Private company|Private]] | founder = [[George Friedman]] | defunct = | area_served = | key_people = [[Chip Harmon]] (President and CEO)
[[Fred Burton (security expert)|Fred Burton]] (VP Intelligence) | industry = [[Intelligence (information gathering)|Publishing]] | products = strategic intelligence, business intelligence, custom intelligence, written and multimedia analysis, corporate security analysis, risk mitigation | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 100 (2015) | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | intl = | caption = | foundation = {{Start date|1996}} | location = [[Austin, Texas]], U.S. | homepage = {{official URL}} }} '''Stratfor''' is an [[United States|American]] geopolitical intelligence platform and [[publisher]] founded in 1996 in [[Austin, Texas]], by [[George Friedman]], who was the company's chairman. Chip Harmon{{Cite web|url=https://www.stratfor.com/horizons/stratfor-appoints-chip-harmon-president-lead-next-phase-growth|title=Stratfor Appoints Chip Harmon as President to Lead Next Phase of Growth|website=Stratfor|language=en|access-date=2018-03-01}} was appointed as president in February 2018. [[Fred Burton (security expert)|Fred Burton]] is Stratfor's chief security officer. Other executives include vice president of global analysis, [https://www.stratfor.com/people/189107 Reva Goujon], senior vice president of strategic analysis, [https://www.stratfor.com/people/189108 Rodger Baker], former [[U.S. Special Operations Command]] officer Bret Boyd, vice president of custom intelligence services.{{cite web|last1=Boyd|first1=Bret |type= Vice President of Custom Intelligence Services|url=http://www.stratfor.com/about/executives/bret-boyd |title=Bret Boyd|website=Stratfor|accessdate=26 June 2014}} ==Products== {{advert|date=August 2016}} Stratfor bills itself as a geopolitical intelligence platform, with revenues derived from individual and enterprise subscriptions to Stratfor Worldview, its online publication, and from custom advisory work for corporate clients. Stratfor has published a daily intelligence briefing since its inception in 1996. Its rise to prominence occurred with the release of its Kosovo Crisis Center during the 1999 [[NATO]] airstrikes over [[Kosovo]], which led to publicity in [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] magazine, ''[[Texas Monthly]]'', and other publications.[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,18728,00.html "Spies Like Us"], ''Time'', January 25, 1999 Before the end of 1999, however, Stratfor had introduced a subscription service through which it offered the majority of its analyses. At the time of the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]], Stratfor made its "breaking news" paragraphs, as well as some notable analyses predicting likely actions to be taken by [[al-Qaeda]] and the [[George W. Bush|Bush]] administration, available freely to the public. Stratfor's publishing business includes written and multimedia analysis available online or through an API, as well as [[iPhone]] and Android mobile applications.[http://www.stratfor.com/tour/products/ Stratfor products] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090927170349/http://www.stratfor.com/tour/products/ |date=2009-09-27 }} Stratfor Threat Lens, an enterprise level product launched in September 2016, offers specific insight and analysis to support [[corporate security]] leaders. In April 2017, the company launched its core online publication under the name [https://worldview.stratfor.com/ Stratfor Worldview]{{Cite web|url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/multimedia-update-stratfor-launches-worldview-revolutionizes-access-geopolitical-intelligence-2212225.htm|title=Stratfor Launches Worldview, Revolutionizes Access to Geopolitical Intelligence, Analysis and Forecasting|last=|first=|date=April 26, 2017|website=Marketwired|access-date=}}. Some of Stratfor's work remains available free to the public.{{cite web|url=http://www.stratfor.com/free-reports|title=Stratfor's Free Intelligence Reports|publisher=Stratfor|accessdate=June 29, 2013}} ==Books and media== Stratfor has published collections of analysis in paperback and as e-books on a variety of topics. Topics include user guides to personal security,{{cite news|last1=Cofall|first1=Dan|title=The Wall Street Shuffle|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jqL3UjTZ9Ws|accessdate=9 July 2014|agency=NorAm Asset Management|date=April 19, 2010|ref=http://www.thewallstreetshuffle.com/category/previous-podcasts/page/2/}} the "devolution of jihadism," and the U.S. war in Afghanistan, according to a series of promotional videos on the company's YouTube channel. Apparently, at one point, the books were sold through a storefront on the company's website. Stratfor e-books and long form analyses are now available through a [https://store.stratfor.com/ dedicated, on-site store]. A number of the company's top analysts have published books in their own name. Notable among these are founder [[George Friedman]] and vice president for intelligence [[Fred Burton (security expert)|Fred Burton]]. Kamran Bokhari, Stratfor's former vice president for Middle East and [[South Asian]] affairs, is the author (with Farid Senzai) of ''Political Islam in the Age of Democratization'' ([[Palgrave Macmillan]], 2013). Reviewer Amani el Sehrawey called the book "an invaluable tool for those seeking to gain knowledge of the nuances of the political systems of the Muslim world from a historical perspective, as well as to understand the contemporary changes happening in the region."{{cite web|last1=El Sehrawey|first1=Amani|title=Book Review: Political Islam in the Age of Democratization by Kamran Bokhari and Farid Senzai|url=http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2014/03/02/book-review-political-islam-in-the-age-of-democratization-by-kamran-bokhari-and-farid-senzai/#Author|website=European Politics and Policy|publisher=London School of Economics and Political Science|accessdate=9 July 2014|ref=March 2, 2014}} ''[[Barron's Magazine|Barron's]]'' once referred to Stratfor as "The Shadow CIA".{{cite web |url=http://online.barrons.com/article/SB1002927557434087960.html |title=The Shadow CIA |last=Laing |first=Jonathan R. |publisher=Barron's magazine |date=October 15, 2001 |accessdate=December 19, 2010 }} ([http://www.rumormillnews.com/cgi-bin/archive.cgi?read=13032 read complete article] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110601025407/http://www.rumormillnews.com/cgi-bin/archive.cgi?read=13032 |date=2011-06-01 }}) Barrons' Jonathan Laing has called Friedman "one of our favorite experts on geopolitics," saying, "His judgments tend to be more nuanced and long-term than those of the press or Wall Street."{{cite news|last1=Laing|first1=Jonathan|title=Putin's Big Miscalculation|url=http://online.barrons.com/news/articles/SB50001424053111904537004580094312032577890?mod=BOL_twm_col|accessdate=19 August 2014|publisher=Barrons|date=16 August 2014}} More recently, ''The Atlantic'''s [[James Fallows]] referenced a Stratfor article on U.S. strategy in Iraq and Ukraine, following outbreaks of turmoil in those regions.{{cite news|last1=Fallows|first1=James|title=Stratfor on American Grand Strategy in Iraq and Ukraine|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2014/06/stratfor-on-american-grand-strategy-in-iraq-and-ukraine/373308/|accessdate=9 July 2014|work=National correspondent|agency=The Atlantic|date=June 24, 2014}} Friedman resigned from the company in 2015 to launch a new company, Geopolitical Futures.Pope, Colin (December 3, 2015). "Stratfor Founder George Friedman Starts Media Business," Austin Business Journal. https://www.bizjournals.com/austin/news/2015/12/03/stratfor-founder-george-friedman-forms.html ==Subscribers== The member and client list for Stratfor is confidential, but the company says it includes [[Fortune 500]] companies, universities and international government agencies as well as professionals who purchase an individual membership{{Cite web|url=https://www.stratfor.com/about-stratfor|title=About Stratfor|website=Stratfor|language=en|access-date=2018-04-20}}. ==Funding== In October 2015, Stratfor raised $12-million in funding through a growth equity investment by Dallas-based Teakwood Capital.{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/austin/blog/techflash/2015/10/austin-security-firm-raises-12m-plans-c-suite-hire.html|title=Austin security firm raises $12M, plans C-suite hire |publisher=[[Bizjournals]]|accessdate=5 November 2015 |date=22 October 2015}} Stratfor's plan for the funding includes expanding its intelligence networks, enhancing operational infrastructure and moving into frontier markets.{{cite news|url=http://www.mystatesman.com/news/business/austins-stratfor-raises-12-million-in-growth-plan/nn6zY/|title=Austin’s Stratfor raises $12 million to fund growth |publisher=Mystatesman|accessdate=5 November 2015 |date=21 October 2015}} == Events == In October 2017, Stratfor sponsored the 2017 Texas National Security Forum organized by Clements Center for National Security, the Robert Strauss Center for International Security and Law, and the Intelligence Studies Project at The University of Texas at Austin{{Cite web|url=https://www.strausscenter.org/event/511.html|title=2017 Texas National Security Forum|last=Dockery|first=Carolyn|website=www.strausscenter.org|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-05-02}}. The theme was "Alliances and Partnerships in American National Security." The event included a keynote address by [[Mike Pompeo|Michael Pompeo]], then director of the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency and later U.S. Secretary of State. Stratfor Chief Security Officer [[Fred Burton (security expert)|Fred Burton]] moderated a panel that included former Acting Director of Central Intelligence John McLaughlin and former Acting Director of the Defense Intelligence Agency [[David Shedd]]. ==Incidents== ===2011 hacking incident=== It was reported on December 24, 2011 that members of [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] had stolen e-mail messages from Stratfor's website.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203479104577120530217909036 |title=Anonymous Claims Hack of Credit Data From Security Group |date=December 25, 2011 |publisher=Wall Street Journal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111226005704/http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052970203479104577120530217909036.html |archivedate=December 26, 2011 }} In November 2013, computer hacker [[Jeremy Hammond]] was sentenced to ten years in federal prison for his role in the Anonymous attack.{{cite news|last=Kopfstein|first=Janus|title=Hacker with a Cause|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/elements/2013/11/jeremy-hammond-and-anonymous-hacker-with-a-cause.html|accessdate=8 March 2014|newspaper=The New Yorker|date=21 November 2013}} An FBI informant, [[Hector Xavier Monsegur]] (also known as "Sabu"), initially faced 124 years in prison for his role in the attack, but his sentence was reduced to time served plus one year's supervised release in May 2014 in exchange for his cooperation as an FBI informant.{{cite news|last1=Pilkington|first1=Ed|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/may/27/hacker-sabu-walks-free-sentenced-time-served|accessdate=26 June 2014|title=LulzSec hacker 'Sabu' released after 'extraordinary' FBI cooperation|publisher=The Guardian|date=May 27, 2014}} ===2012 leak=== {{main|2012 Stratfor email leak}} [[WikiLeaks]] announced the initial publication of more than five million of Stratfor's e-mail messages on February 26, 2012.{{cite news| url=https://wikileaks.org/the-gifiles.html | work=[[WikiLeaks]] | title=The Global Intelligence Files | date=February 27, 2012}} Anonymous claimed to have provided WikiLeaks with the data.{{cite web|author=Andy Greenberg |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2012/02/27/wikileaks-tightens-ties-to-anonymous-in-leak-of-stratfor-emails/ |title=WikiLeaks Tightens Ties To Anonymous In Leak Of Stratfor Emails |publisher=Forbes |date= |accessdate=2012-02-27}} George Friedman stated that third parties may have forged or altered the e-mail messages, but that Stratfor would not validate either alterations or authenticity. {{cite news | url= http://stratfor.com/hacking-news/subscriber-info | work=Stratfor | title=George Friedman on Email Theft and the WikiLeaks Release | date=February 28, 2012 | quote = Some of the emails may be forged or altered to include inaccuracies. Some may be authentic. We will not validate either [...] }} Stratfor condemned the release as "deplorable".{{cite news| url= http://stratfor.com/hacking-news | work=Stratfor | title=George Friedman on Email Theft and the WikiLeaks Release | date=February 28, 2012}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book|author=Friedman, George|title=America's secret war: inside the hidden worldwide struggle between the United States and its enemies|publisher=Random House|year=2005|isbn=978-0-7679-1785-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Cz0qT-m1WdsC}} *Friedman, George, [http://www.stratfor.com/weekly/20090420_torture_and_u_s_intelligence_failure#axzz3LQKKLpE1 ''Torture and the U.S. Intelligence Failure''], Stratfor, Geopolitical Weekly, April 20, 2009 *Judson, David, [https://worldview.stratfor.com/article/geopolitical-intelligence-political-journalism-and-wants-vs-needs Geopolitical Intelligence, Political Journalism and "Wants" vs. "Needs"], Stratfor, October 29, 2013 *Judson, David, [https://worldview.stratfor.com/article/stratfor-test-being-rorschach-test Stratfor: The Test of Being a Rorschach Test], Stratfor Worldview, On Stratfor, August 28, 2016 *Judson, David, [https://worldview.stratfor.com/article/new-generation-comes-new-worldview With a New Generation Comes a New Worldview], Stratfor Worldview, On Stratfor, May 21, 2017 ==External links== * {{official}} * [http://english.al-akhbar.com/content/stratfor-inside-world-private-cia Stratfor: Inside the World of a Private CIA] [[Category:Companies established in 1996]] [[Category:Intelligence websites]] [[Category:Companies based in Austin, Texas]] [[Category:Foreign policy and strategy think tanks in the United States]] [[Category:Open-source intelligence]] [[Category:Political and economic think tanks in the United States]] [[Category:Security studies]] [[Category:Private intelligence agencies]]

{{Infobox Congressman | name = Stuyvesant Wainwright | image name = SWainwright.png | image_size = 180px | state = [[New York (state)|New York]] | district = [[United States House of Representatives, New York District 1|1st]] | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | term_start = January 3, 1953 | term_end = January 3, 1961 | preceded = [[Ernest Greenwood]] | succeeded = [[Otis G. Pike]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1921|3|16}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], New York | death_date = {{death date and age|2010|3|6|1921|3|16}} | death_place = [[Wainscott, New York]] | parents = [[Carroll Livingston Wainwright I|Carroll Livingston Wainwright]]
Edith Catherine Gould | spouse = {{marriage|Janet Isabel Parsons
|1941}} | children = 4 | relatives = [[Loudon Wainwright Jr.]] (cousin)
[[George Jay Gould I|George Jay Gould]] (grandfather) | religion = | occupation = | residence = | education = [[Westminster School (Connecticut)|Westminster School]] | alma_mater = [[Yale Law School]] | allegiance = {{USA}} | serviceyears = 1942-1945 | rank = [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|Lieutenant Colonel]] | branch = [[United States Army]] | battles = [[World War II]] }} '''Stuyvesant Wainwright II''' (March 16, 1921 – March 6, 2010) was a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] member of the [[United States House of Representatives]] from [[New York (state)|New York]].{{cite web |url=http://www.easthamptonstar.com/dnn/Obituaries/tabid/11505/Default.aspx |title=Obituaries - March 11, 2010 Stuyvesant Wainwright II, Former United States Representative |accessdate=2010-03-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100401111058/http://www.easthamptonstar.com/dnn/Obituaries/tabid/11505/Default.aspx |archivedate=April 1, 2010 |df= }} ==Early life== Wainwright was born in [[New York City]], the son of [[Carroll Livingston Wainwright I|Carroll Livingston Wainwright]] (1899–1967) and Edith Catherine Gould (d. 1937),{{cite news|title=Carroll Wainwright, Artist and Member Of L.I. Family, Dies|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1967/07/07/archives/carroll-wainwright-artist-and-member-of-li-family-dies.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=7 July 1967}} daughter of financier [[George Jay Gould I|George Jay Gould]] (1864-1923) and Edith M. Kingdon (1864-1921). His siblings were Carroll L. Wainwright Jr. (1925–2016){{cite news|last1=Fox|first1=Margalit|title=Carroll Wainwright Jr., ‘Silk-Stockinged Stowaway,’ Dies at 90|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/02/nyregion/carroll-wainwright-dead.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=1 October 2016}} and Caroline Wainwright (d. 1969), and his paternal grandparents were Stuyvesant Wainwright (d. 1975){{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=Stuyvesant Wainwright Dead; Bridge Player and Broker, 84|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1975/02/05/archives/stuyvesant-wainwright-dead-bridge-player-and-broker-84.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=5 February 1975}} and Caroline Smith Snowden. His grandmother later married Carl F. Wolff. He was a great-nephew of General [[Jonathan M. Wainwright (general)|Jonathan Mayhew Wainwright]] (1883–1953), a four star-general who was the hero of [[Battle of Bataan|Bataan]] and commander of the U.S. forces in the [[Philippines]] during World War II. His uncle, Loudon Wainwright, was the father of [[Loudon Wainwright Jr.]] (his cousin), and the grandfather of [[Loudon Wainwright III]], the singer and songwriter, himself the father of [[Rufus Wainwright]], [[Martha Wainwright]], and [[Lucy Wainwright Roche]]. In 1927, his family moved to [[East Hampton (town), New York|East Hampton, New York]] where they built an imposing house called "Gulf Crest," that was valued at $350,000 in 1937. His parents divorced in 1932 and his mother married Sir Hector MacNeal, the Scottish shipowner.{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=LADY M'NEAL DIES; WAS EDITH GOULD; Granddaughter of Financier, 36, Succumbs at Estate in East Hampton; WIFE OF BRITISH KNIGHT; Wrote Autobiography Telling of Family Life as a Child -- Niece of Duchess|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1937/09/12/archives/lady-mneal-dies-was-edith-gould-granddaughter-of-financier-36.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=12 September 1937}} He attended the [[Westminster School (Connecticut)|Westminster School]], [[Simsbury, Connecticut]] and, later, graduated from [[Yale Law School]] in 1947. ==Career== On January 30, 1942, at the age of 20, he left Yale and enlisted as a private in the [[United States Army]]. He attended officers candidate school and on December 30, 1943, went overseas during [[World War II]]. He rose through the ranks, and was commanding officer of [[Office of Strategic Services]], a wartime [[intelligence agency]] during World War II that was a predecessor of the modern [[Central Intelligence Agency]].{{cite web|last=Clancey|first=Patrick|title=Office of Strategic Services (OSS) Organization and Functions|url=http://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/USG/JCS/OSS/OSS-Functions/index.html|publisher=HyperWar|accessdate=Nov 10, 2016}} He returned to the U.S. on June 10, 1945, and spent the last three months of his service as adviser on intelligence coordination in the War Department in [[Washington, D.C.]] He was honorably discharged as a Captain from the Army on December 13, 1945. After the War, he served in the [[United States Army Reserve|Active Army Reserve]], and retired as a [[Lieutenant colonel (United States)|Lieutenant Colonel]] in 1960. He resumed his legal studies at Yale, graduated in 1947, was admitted to the [[New York State Bar]] in 1948, and began practicing in New York City, where he was a partner in the firm of Walker, [[Bouvier Beale|Beale]], Wainwright & Wolf. ===United States Congress=== In [[United States elections, 1952|1952]], he was elected to Congress in the Republican wave that flipped the [[U.S. House of Representatives|House]], [[U.S. Senate|Senate]] and [[U.S. President|Presidency]] from [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] to Republican.{{cite web|title=Statistics of the Presidential and Congressional election of November 4, 1952|url=http://clerk.house.gov/member_info/electionInfo/1952election.pdf|publisher=U.S. House of Reps, Office of the Clerk|accessdate=27 December 2011}} Wainwright went on to serve three consecutive terms as the Representative for [[New York's 1st congressional district]]{{cite web|last1=Rosenthal|first1=Howard L.|last2=Poole|first2=Keith T.|title=Stuyvesant Wainwright, former Representative for New York's 1st Congressional District - GovTrack.us|url=https://www.govtrack.us/congress/members/stuyvesant_wainwright/411203|website=GovTrack.us|publisher=[[GovTrack]]|accessdate=25 April 2017}} from January 3, 1953 until January 3, 1961, in the [[83rd United States Congress|83rd]], [[84th United States Congress|84th]], and [[85th United States Congress]]es.{{cite web|title=WAINWRIGHT, Stuyvesant, II - Biographical Information|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=W000024|website=bioguide.congress.gov|publisher=[[Biographical Directory of the United States Congress]]|accessdate=25 April 2017}} While serving in Congress, he was a member of the [[House Armed Services Committee]],{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=Wainwright to Parachute|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1959/05/01/archives/wainwright-to-parachute.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=1 May 1959}} [[United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs|Foreign Affairs Committee]], the [[United States House Committee on Education and the Workforce|Education and Labor Committee]] and the [[United States House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries|Merchant Marine Committee]]. He narrowly lost a re-election bid in 1960 against [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] [[Otis G. Pike]].{{cite news|last1=Porterfield|first1=Byron|title=State's First and 28th Districts Are G. O. P. Strongholds; Pike Is Challenging Wainwright on L.I. for Congress Seat|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1958/10/14/archives/states-first-and-28th-districts-are-g-o-p-strongholds-pike-is.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=14 October 1958}}{{cite news|last1=Porterfield|first1=Byron|title=Pike, in First, Tries Again to Unseat Wainwright|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1960/10/19/archives/pike-in-first-tries-again-to-unseat-wainwright.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=19 October 1960}} ===Later career=== After leaving the House of Representatives, he taught political science at [[Rutgers University]] from 1960 to 1961. Afterwards, he resumed the practice of law with the firm Battle, Fowler, Lidstone, Jaffin, Pierce & Kheel. From 1975 until 1979, he was president of the Miltope Corporation, and a director of the Corporation from 1975-1985. ==Personal life== In 1941, Wainwright was married to Janet Isabel Parsons (1920–2000),{{cite news|title=WAINWRIGHT, JANET PARSONS|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/05/21/classified/paid-notice-deaths-wainwright-janet-parsons.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=21 May 2000}} the daughter of Thomas Crouse Parsons.{{cite news|title=TROTH ANNOIJHCED OF JANET PARSONS; Texas Girl to Become Bride of Stuyvesant Wainwright 2d, Yale University Student SHE ATTENDED BREARLEY Also Studied at Miss Porter's Her Fianoe Grandson of Late George J, Goulds|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1941/04/17/archives/troth-annoijhced-of-janet-parsons-texas-girl-to-become-bride-of.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=17 April 1941}}{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New Tors|title=JANET PARSONS WED TO S. WAINWRIGHT 2D; Former Hew York Girl Bride of Jay Gonld's Descendant|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1941/06/13/archives/janet-parsons-wed-to-s-wainwright-2d-former-hew-york-girl-bride-of.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=13 June 1941}} Before their divorce, they were the parents of: * Stuyvesant Wainwright III * Jonathan Mayhew Wainwright (b. 1944){{cite news|title=Son to the S. Wainwrights 2d|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1944/04/06/archives/son-to-the-s-wainwrights-2d.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=6 April 1944}} * Janet Snowden Wainwright, who married Charles Brandon Waring in 1967.{{cite news|title=Miss Wainwright Engaged to Wed Charles Waring; George Washington U. Students Planning to Marry in Autumn|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1967/02/16/archives/miss-wainwright-engaged-to-wed-charles-waring-george-washington-u.html|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=16 February 1967}} * Laura Wainwright Until his death he was a resident of [[Wainscott, New York]] and lived on [[Georgica Pond]].{{cite news|title=WAINWRIGHT, STUYVESANT II|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0CE4DC1E3AF937A25750C0A9669D8B63|accessdate=25 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=14 March 2010}} a [[census-designated place]] that roughly corresponds to the [[Hamlet (New York)|hamlet]] with the same name in the [[Administrative divisions of New York#Town|Town]] of [[East Hampton (town), New York|East Hampton]] in [[Suffolk County, New York|Suffolk County]], [[New York (state)|New York]], on the [[South Fork, Suffolk County, New York|South Fork]] of [[Long Island]].{{Cite web| url=http://factfinder2.census.gov/bkmk/table/1.0/en/DEC/10_DP/G001/1600000US3677805| title=Geographic Identifiers: 2010 Demographic Profile Data (G001): Wainscott CDP, New York| publisher=U.S. Census Bureau, American Factfinder| accessdate=2013-01-10}} He served on the Boards of the [[Southampton Hospital]], Guild Hall of East Hampton, the vestry of St. Luke's Church in East Hampton, the [[Maidstone Club]] of East Hampton and the [[Union Club of the City of New York]]. He was also a member of [[Cruising Club of America]] and [[Royal Bermuda Yacht Club]]. ==References== ;Notes {{reflist|30em}} ;Sources {{CongBio|W000024}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox | state=New York | district=1 | before=[[Ernest Greenwood]]| after=[[Otis G. Pike]]| years=1953–1961 }} {{s-end}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wainwright, Stuyvesant}} [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American politicians]] [[Category:People from East Hampton (town), New York]] [[Category:Politicians from New York City]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from New York (state)]] [[Category:Westminster School (Connecticut) alumni]] [[Category:Yale Law School alumni]] [[Category:New York (state) lawyers]] [[Category:New York (state) Republicans]] [[Category:American army personnel of World War II‎]] [[Category:People of the Office of Strategic Services]] [[Category:United States Army colonels]] [[Category:United States Army reservists]] [[Category:Republican Party members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:Gould family]] [[Category:Livingston family]] [[Category:Stuyvesant family]] [[Category:Wainwright family|Stuyvesant]]

{{Infobox journal | cover = RAND Journal cover.png | discipline = [[Economics]] | former_names = The Bell Journal of Economics and Management Science
The Bell Journal of Economics | abbreviation = RAND J. Econ. | publisher = [[Wiley-Blackwell]] for [[RAND]] | country = [[United States|USA]] | frequency = Quarterly | history = 1970-present | openaccess = | impact = 1.465 | impact-year = 2016 | website = http://www.rje.org/ | link1 = https://www.jstor.org/journal/belljeconomics | link1-name = ''The Bell Journal of Economics'' archive | link2 = https://www.jstor.org/journal/belljeconmanasci | link2-name = ''The Bell Journal of Economics and Management'' archive | ISSN = 0741-6261 | ISSN2label = Bell Journal: | ISSN2 = 0361-915X | JSTOR = 07416261 }} The '''''RAND Journal of Economics'''''[http://www.rje.org/ Webpage of The ''RAND Journal of Economics''] (usually called '''''Rand Journal''''' or simply '''''Rand''''' ) is a [[peer-review]]ed scholarly journal of [[economics]] published quarterly by [[Wiley-Blackwell]] on behalf of the [[RAND Corporation]].[http://www.rand.org/ Webpage of The RAND Corporation] The journal's purpose is "to support and encourage research in the behavior of regulated industries, the economic analysis of organizations, and more generally, applied microeconomics". It publishes both theoretical and empirical papers. According to the ''[[Journal Citation Reports]]'', the journal has a 2016 [[impact factor]] of 1.465, ranking it 98th out of 347 journals in the category "Economics".{{cite book |year=2017 |chapter=Journals Ranked by Impact: Economics |title=2016 [[Journal Citation Reports]] |publisher=[[Clarivate Analytics]] |edition=Science |series=[[Web of Science]]}} == History == AT&T's [[Bell Labs]] economics group launched the journal in the spring of 1970 with the name '''''The Bell Journal of Economics and Management Science'''''.Michael Crew and David Parker (Eds.).''International Handbook on Economic Regulation''. Cheltenham, U.K.: Edward Elgar, 2006, p. 6. From 1975–1983 it was titled '''''The Bell Journal of Economics'''''. In 1984, after transfer to the [[RAND Corporation]], it acquired its present name. {{clear}} ==See also== {{Portal|Economics|Literature}} * [[List of economics journals]] {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:RAND Journal Of Economics, Te}} [[Category:Economics journals]] [[Category:Industrial organization]] [[Category:Publications established in 1970]] [[Category:Quarterly journals]] [[Category:RAND Corporation]] [[Category:Wiley-Blackwell academic journals]]

page.title: Whitfield family of the United States

revision.text:
{{about|the American Whitfield family|the British main branch|Whitfield family|other uses|Whitfield (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox Family |colour = powderblue |name = The Whitfield Family |crest = |footnotes = |caption = |early_forms = |members = [[William Whitfield I]]
[[William Whitfield II]]
[[William Whitfield III]]
[[Henry L. Whitfield]]
[[James B. Whitfield]]
[[James Whitfield (Mississippi)|James Whitfield]]
[[Nathan Bryan Whitfield]] |otherfamilies = Herring family, Bryan family, Wooten family |distinctions = [[Plantations in the American South#Planter .28plantation owner.29|Planters]] ([[American gentry]]) |traditions = |heirlooms = |estate = |meaning = Hoit-Feldt, Norse for "white field" |ethnicity = [[Normans|Norman]] |origin = [[United Kingdom]] |region = [[United States]] |birth_place = }} The '''Whitfield family''' was a prominent slave-owning [[List of United States political families|American political family]] of the [[Southern United States|Southern states]], and of the Northern United States having established https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Whitfield_House the Henry Whitfield House in 1639 in the town of Guilford, Connecticut. Historically, it is Connecticut's oldest house. The house, with its massive stone walls, also served as a fort to protect the community Henry Whitfield, for whom the house was built, was a Puritan minister who had come from England to flee religious persecution The house was remodeled in 1868 and opened to the public in 1899 as the first museum of the State of Connecticut, the Henry Whitfield State Museum. The house was restored in 1902–04 and in the 1930s and was declared a National Historic Landmark in 1997. It was named a State Archeological Preserve in 2006. In the Southern States, the Whitfields formed the American branch of the British [[Whitfield family]] - having descended from the [[British aristocracy]], particularly the [[Earls of Kilmorey]] and having established colonial residency under Sir. Thomas Whitfield, whom headed East India Trading for the British Empire. In early days of [[Colonial America]], the family [[First Families of Virginia|emigrated to Virginia]] in the seventeenth century, particularly, [[Nansemond County, Virginia]] from [[Lancashire, England]].{{cite book |last= Connelley|first= William Elsey|date= 1923|title= History Of Kentucky, Volume 5|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=Vi8VAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|location= |publisher=Nabu Press |page= 914|isbn=978-1273257155 |access-date=August 12, 2013}}{{cite book |last= Hathaway|first= James Robert Bent|date= 1900|title= The North Carolina Historical and Genealogical Register, Volume 1|url= https://books.google.com/books/about/The_North_Carolina_Historical_and_Geneal.html?id=j9YUAAAAYAAJ|location= |publisher= |page= |isbn= |access-date=August 12, 2013}} The family produced many [[United States]] [[United States House of Representatives|Congressmen]], [[US Senator|Senators]] and [[Governor (United States)|Governors]], as well as businessmen and military generals active from the [[American Revolutionary War]] and past the [[American Civil War]], with significance during the [[antebellum period]]. The family is most connected to the [[North Carolina|U.S. State of North Carolina]], but had extended [[Plantations in the American South|land ownership]], [[Slavery in the United States|slave trade]], business activities and public service to [[Louisiana]], [[Alabama]], [[Kentucky]], [[Mississippi]] and [[Florida]].{{cite book |last= Scarborough|first= William Kauffman|date= 2006|title= Masters of the Big House: Elite Slaveholders of the Mid-Nineteenth-Century South|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=BC5eMgbZeK8C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|location= |publisher= Louisiana State University Press |page= 521 |isbn= 978-0807131558|access-date=April 4, 2006}} ==Background== [[File:Gaineswood_in_October_2011_01.JPG|thumb|The [[Gaineswood]] plantation home.]] [[File:Gaineswood_Ballroom.jpg|thumb|Ballroom at Gaineswood.]] Born in [[Lancashire]], [[England]], patriarch [[William Whitfield I]] moved to [[Nansemond County, Virginia]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=lHIxq9iDgYQC&pg=PA569&lpg=PA569&dq=william+whitfield+iii+genealogy&source=bl&ots=I4L4bgJvYP&sig=WkNK1zcDNzqLlBKGHNt1t0K5-qY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=dxGtVMazKtiBygSNiYLYAg&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=william%20whitfield%20iii%20genealogy&f=false The North Carolina Historical and Genealogical Register] Volume I In 1770, Whitfield, along with his wife, were killed by the [[Tuscarora people|Tuscarora Indians]]. His son, [[William Whitfield II]] purchased [[Seven Springs, North Carolina]] from Buckskin Williams, the father of [[Benjamin Williams]], the [[Governor of North Carolina]].{{cite book |last= |first= |authorlink= |title= Daughters of the American Revolution|url= |accessdate= |year= |publisher=[[Daughters of the American Revolution|DAR]] |location= |isbn= |page=385}} During the [[American Revolutionary War]], he served as a [[Captain (United States)|Captain]] of the [[6th Virginia Regiment]], along with his sons, Needham Whitfield and [[William Whitfield III]] who were in the [[Battle of Moore's Creek Bridge]] during the revolutionary war. The former was a clerk to Colonel [[Richard Caswell]] and the other a private in the Light Horse [[Cavalry]], taking prisoner General McDonald, who was the Commander of the [[Loyalist (American Revolution)|Tories]].{{cite book |last=Whitfield |first=Emma |authorlink= |title=Whitfield, Bryan, Smith & Related Families |url= |accessdate= |year= |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=}} Whitfield II was a [[Dobbs County, North Carolina|Dobbs County]] member to the 1761 and 1762 [[North Carolina General Assembly]] held in [[Wilmington, North Carolina|Wilmington]]. In 1779 he was a member of Governor [[Richard Caswell]]'s Council held in New Berne, and a [[Justice of Peace]] for [[Johnston County, North Carolina]]. He was later a [[Colonel]].{{cite book |last= |first= |authorlink= |title=Whitfield Record, The North Carolina historical and genealogical register. Vol I, Number 4 |url= |accessdate= |year=1900 |publisher= |location= |isbn= |pages=567–576}} Whitfield III in turn, was also appointed [[Justice of the Peace]] for Dobbs County in 1778. Along with his son, he was a Director and Trustee for designing and building the town of [[Goldsboro, North Carolina|Wanesboro]]. He had 29 children[http://walkofhonor.com/whitfield_william_army.html Whitfield, William, Battle of Moore's Creek Bridge] and forty of his descendants served in the [[confederate army]] during the American Civil war. This included, [[Nathan Bryan Whitfield]], William III's nephew, who became the Counselor of State for the State of North Carolina and was a State Senator. He was later commissioned to [[Major General]] rank to succeed his father for the militia. His son, Dr. Bryan Watkins Whitfield, was [[List of people pardoned or granted clemency by the President of the United States|pardoned]] by U.S. President [[Andrew Johnson]] on September 12, 1865.[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/67161672 Dr Bryan Watkins Whitfield] at [[Find a Grave]]. [[Gaineswood]], which still stands today, was the most significant remaining examples of [[Greek Revival architecture]] in Alabama.Gamble, Robert ''Historic architecture in Alabama: a guide to styles and types, 1810-1930'', page 76. Tuscaloosa, Alabama: The University of Alabama Press, 1990. {{ISBN|0-8173-1134-3}}. was designed and built by Whitfield, beginning in 1843 as an open-hall log dwelling. Whitfield is known to have designed most of the house from pattern books by [[James Stuart (1713-1788)|James Stuart]], [[Minard Lafever]], [[Nicholas Revett]] and others. Much of the work on the house was executed by highly skilled [[artisan]] slaves. Whitfield moved from [[North Carolina]] to Marengo County, Alabama in 1834. In 1842 Whitfield bought the {{convert|480|acre|km2|adj=on}} property from [[George Strother Gaines]], younger brother of [[Edmund P. Gaines]]. [[File:Gaineswood_Library.jpg|thumb|The library inside the [[Gaineswood]] residence.]] Much of the work on the house was executed by highly skilled [[artisan]] slaves. The grounds had been the site of a notable historic event while owned by George Gaines. When Gaines was serving as the US [[Indian Agent]], he is said to have met with the famous [[Tribal chief|chief]] [[Pushmataha]], of the [[Choctaw]] Nation, under an old [[post oak]] tree on what would become the Gaineswood estate. They were negotiating the terms of the treaty that would lead to the Choctaw [[Indian removal|removal]] to [[Indian Territory]]. The tree became known as the Pushmataha Oak.Hammond, Ralph ''Ante-bellum Mansions of Alabama'', pages 114-120. New York: Architectural Book Publishers, 1951. {{ISBN|0-517-02075-0}} Whitfield first named the estate Marlmont in 1843; he renamed it Gaineswood in 1856 in honor of Gaines.Marengo County Heritage Book Committee: ''The heritage of Marengo County, Alabama'', page 18. Clanton, Alabama: Heritage Publishing Consultants, 2000. {{ISBN|1-891647-58-X}} The Whitfield family tradition maintained that Gaines' original log house was the nucleus around which Whitfield had the mansion built, and that it was located at the present site of the south entrance hall and office."{{cite web|title=Gaineswood|work="Alabama Historical Commission"|url=http://www.preserveala.org/gaineswood.aspx?sm=g_i|accessdate=2007-09-18}} Gen. Whitfield sold the house to his son, Dr. Bryan Watkins Whitfield, in 1861. The second generation of Whitfields maintained Gaineswood as a residence. Mary Foscue Whitfield inherited the nearby [[Foscue-Whitfield House]] in 1861 upon her father's death and used that as a residence as well. For later descendants, post Civil War, the lands and plantations were sold. ==Members== [[File:Nathan Bryan Whitfield 2.jpg|thumb|General [[Nathan Bryan Whitfield]], portrait at [[Gaineswood]].]] *[[William Whitfield II]] (1715-1795) — Member of the [[North Carolina General Assembly]] from [[Dobbs County, North Carolina|Dobbs County]] (1761 - 1762). In 1779 he was a member of Governor [[Richard Caswell]]'s Council, and a [[Justice of Peace]] for [[Johnston County, North Carolina]]. [[Captain (United States)|Captain]] of the [[6th Virginia Regiment]] during the [[American Revolutionary War]]. **[[William Whitfield III]] (1743-1817) — Fought in the [[Battle of Moore's Creek Bridge]] during the [[American Revolutionary War]]. Appointed [[Justice of the peace]] for Dobbs County in 1778. **Benjamin Bryan Whitfield (1754-1817) — Member of [[North Carolina House of Commons|North Carolina General Assembly]] representing from [[Dobbs County, North Carolina|Dobbs County]], 1786-87. Served in the Continental Army during the Revolutionary War as a [[General]]. ***[[Nathan Bryan Whitfield]] (1799-1868) — Member of [[North Carolina House of Commons|North Carolina General Assembly]] from Lenoir County, 1821; Member of [[North Carolina Senate]] from Lenoir County, 1822–23, 1825, 1827. [[General]] of the [[North Carolina]] militia during the war. [[File:James whitfield Gov.jpg|thumb|Governor [[James Whitfield (Mississippi)|James Whitfield]]]] [[File:Jbwhitfield.jpg|thumb|Justice [[James B. Whitfield]]]] ***James Bryan Whitfield (1809-1841) — Member of [[North Carolina Senate]] of the 17th District, 1840-41. ****Nathan Bryan Whitfield (1835-1914) — Member of [[North Carolina House of Commons|North Carolina House of Representatives]] from [[Lenoir County, North Carolina]] (1858–59, 1891–92). [[Colonel]] in the [[Union Army]] during the [[American Civil War]]. *****[[James B. Whitfield]] (1860-1948) — 11th [[State Treasurer of Florida]] (1897-1903), 17th [[Florida Attorney General|Attorney General of Florida]] (1903-1904), and [[Chief Justice]] of the [[Supreme Court of Florida]]. Grandfather of Dr. [[Randolph Whitfield, Jr]], brother-in-law of astronaut [[Rusty Schweickart]]. ===Others=== [[File:HL whitfield Gov.jpg|thumb|[[List of Governors of Mississippi|Governor]] [[Henry L. Whitfield]]]] *[[James Whitfield (Mississippi)|James Whitfield]] (1791-1875) — 18th [[Governor of Mississippi]], 1851-52. Member of [[Mississippi House of Representatives|Mississippi State House of Representatives]], 1842–50, 1858–62; member of [[Mississippi State Senate]], 1851. Grandnephew of [[William Whitfield II]]. **[[Henry L. Whitfield]] (1868 -1927) — 41st [[Governor of Mississippi]], Delegate to the [[1924 Democratic National Convention]] from [[Mississippi]]. Great-great-great grandson of [[William Whitfield II]]. *Needham Bryan (1749-1787) — Member of [[North Carolina State Senate|North Carolina Senate]] from Johnston County, 1777–79; member of [[North Carolina House of Commons|North Carolina General Assembly]] from Johnston County, 1786. First cousin of Benjamin Bryan Whitfield. **Lovard Bryan (1769-1798) — Member of [[North Carolina House of Commons|North Carolina General Assembly]] from Johnston County, 1791-92. **David Hardy Bryan (1753-1820) — Member of [[North Carolina House of Commons|North Carolina General Assembly]] from Johnston County, 1781, 1785, 1790; member of [[North Carolina State Senate|North Carolina Senate]] from Johnston County, 1783, 1792-93. First cousin once removed of Nathan Bryan Whitfield (1799-1868). **Joseph Hunter Bryan (1782-1839) — Member of [[North Carolina House of Commons|North Carolina General Assembly]], 1804–05, 1807–09; [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] from [[North Carolina]], ([[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], 2nd District) at the fourteenth and fifteenth Congress, 1815-19. Third cousin of David Hardy Bryan. ***Henry Hunter Bryan (1786-1835) — [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] from [[Tennessee]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]]), (at-large) at the sixteenth Congress, 1819-21. Third cousin of David Hardy Bryan. ****Auburn Bascomb Bryan (1873-1942) — Alternate delegate of [[North Carolina]] to the [[1924 Republican National Convention]]. Second great-grandnephew of David Hardy Bryan. ==See also== *[[Henry Whitfield House]] *[[The House Place Plantation]] *[[Bryan Whitfield Herring Farm]] *[[Needham Whitfield Herring House]] *[[Foscue-Whitfield House]] *[[Gaineswood|Gaineswood Plantation House]] *[[Welaunee Plantation, Florida]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://politicalgraveyard.com/families/12160.html Bryan-Whitfield Family] at [[The Political Graveyard]] *[http://www2.lib.unc.edu/mss/inv/w/Whitfield_Family.html Whitfield Family Papers, 1796-1918] and [http://www2.lib.unc.edu/mss/inv/c/Cobb_and_Whitfield_Family.html 1736-1946] at Southern Historical Collection at the [[University of North Carolina]] *[http://www.lib.auburn.edu/archive/find-aid/863.htm Whitfield Family Papers, 1863-1990] at Special Collections & Archives Department, [[Auburn University]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Whitfield family}} [[Category:American families of English ancestry]] [[Category:Business families of the United States]] [[Category:Political families of the United States]] [[Category:American genealogy]] [[Category:Whitfield family]]
